9/ The point is crypto is not like other assets. If they are not securities, we cant just lump them into a default definition of "property" as that creates further issues. So if anything this is a step towards crypto becoming its own class of asset with independent tax treatment.

8/ So now the IRS needs to defend their position by preventing loopholes from being created in areas where they probably never thought they would have potential issues. And that is where the victory is. Even if the IRS wins against the Jarrett's, a bigger point has been made.

7/ See the Jarrett's did not create their Tezos reward, they merely provided the property to do so. This will take some guidance and an official ruling/publication by the IRS to provide clarity. If crypto was treated more as a security, this wouldnt even be a question.

6/ That is where the argument is a bit weak. The IRS can easily argue that the Jarrett's were the recipient of increased value, not the creator. Using the sculpture example, the Jarrett's merely gave Michelangelo a giant rock, and he gave them back David.

5/ These actions have to be looked as crypto is property and not currency. When a Taxpayer "creates" property, there is no taxable event until the property is sold. That is like an artist making a sculpture. The Jarrett's are arguing they "created" these staking rewards.

4/ The argument is that by staking Tezos, the Taxpayers direct action lead to rewards. So are the receipt of these rewards taxable? The Jarrett's say no. I feel that this is actually the first case where the IRS blanket statement of "crypto is property" comes back to bite them.

3/ Instead of contesting the denied return out of court (which would have been the easier/cheaper option), the Jarrett's filed in District Court to force the IRS to make an official ruling on this matter. Please read the Court Order for yourself:

https://t.co/KNdDqaxu9d

2/ First let's break down what is actually happening. The Jarrett's have made a claim for refund for taxes paid on staking rewards. Its likely an amended tax return was filed showing a reduced tax, which the IRS likely denied.  In response, the Jarrett's likely filed this claim.

1/ There's been a lot of buzz about the following  news.  Here's my two cents on how a ruling like this could go in court.

8/ and finally
3) another downside of wash sales is the fact you‚Äôre reducing your basis in the asset by recognizing the loss. So when you sell it in the future you will have more gains.

7/ This could prevent you from classifying your crypto as long term capital assets and thus you‚Äôd be missing out on the more favorable capital gains tax rate. In many instances you could pay 20% more in taxes. So those recognized losses better be worth it.

6/ But more importantly..

2) When you sell your crypto you are resetting the holding period. When you hold an asset for less than a year, gains are taxed as ordinary income. Wash sales set your holding period back to zero.

5/ So why not sell your crypto to recognize losses and buy it back immediately? Three reasons:

1) You are banking that the IRS isn‚Äôt going to retroactively prohibit the sale as it applies to crypto. Audit risk is high in this space getting away with the loss isn‚Äôt guaranteed

4/ Th IRS change makes it more uncertain for investors to get their assets back as the same price as the proceeds from their sale. 

People are now discussing wash sales because the limitation rules only apply to securities. As we know, crypto is property. Not a security.

3/ However, the IRS disallowed wash sale losses for securities if the asset was repurchased within 30 days. 

See: https://t.co/rgZj25emMA

2/ First what is a wash sale? It occurs when an investor is holding an asset (typically a security) that has an unrealized loss. The investor then sells the asset at a loss and immediately buys it back. This allows them to keep their asset and recognize the loss.

1/ Short-ish thread on Wash Sales:

Big concept floating around year end for crypto currencies (not NFTs since they are illiquid) is this idea that crypto currency is currently not subject to the wash sale rules. Here‚Äôs why it still may not be the best idea.
GM frens! 8 days left in the year. Plan wisely

@ADegenerateSol Technically speaking, OpenSea is just a marketplace. So even if a project gets pulled from the marketplace, you still own the asset. 

Now does it reduce its value? Probably, but you‚Äôd have to find a way to sell it in order to recognize the loss.

3/ If you sell to someone for less than fair market value then that transaction can be considered a part sale/part gift.  This means that while you are selling an asset, the difference between sale price and fair market value is a gift. This disallows the loss as well.

2/ The main way the IRS can disallow the loss is by claiming a related party transaction. See IRC 267

Selling to yourself is automatically disallowed. If your follow up question is ‚ÄúHow will the IRS know?‚Äù Then you‚Äôre considering fraudulent reporting. üëé

1/ Common question:

Can I sell an NFT to another wallet I own or my friends wallet in order to recognize a loss?

The reality is that whenever you ‚Äúsell‚Äù an asset to yourself or a friend at a discounted price, the IRS can potentially disallow the loss.
@_smtd_ Transferring to yourself in another wallet isn‚Äôt really considered a ‚Äúsale‚Äù so you wouldn‚Äôt be able to realize and gain/loss.
IRS wants to know‚Ä¶ did you buy/sell crypto in 2021? https://t.co/a5DhagEbAk

Here‚Äôs the main source of guidance from the IRS regarding cryptocurrency. The main takeaway is that all virtual currency and NFTs are considered property. They are not nor should ever be considered securities.

IRS Notice 2014-21
https://t.co/Ap0MH7yX29
